text: all righty thank you for joining me um
yeah I'm going to talk a bit about the
new open feature multi-provider and some
of the kind of unique use cases um that
you can enable with it combining
multiple providers together with open
feature uh who am I i think probably
most of you have heard me talk today as
have been mceing this but um I'm the
co-founder and CTO at DevCycle um at
DevCycle we launched in 2022 um proud to
say we're I think the only feature
flagging platform that comes with open
feature built into all of our SDKs
strong supporters of the open feature
platform and um yeah and I'm actually
part of the governance board now um I've
been building AB testing and feature
flagging products for over 10 years um
our company Tapalytics Tapollettics was
our original product we um did Y
Combinator back in winter 2014 which is
like ages ago which is crazy um and we
uh it's the same company tapitics we we
built our second product dev cycle um in
um multi-provider so I think most of you
or a lot of you have probably seen this
diagram from um from the open feature
docs website hopefully but I'll go
through it pretty briefly so um the
basis of how open feature works is that
you have your application um that you
want to retrieve feature flag values for
and you use the open feature SDK is that
main interface between your app um and
and um the your feature flagging
provider um so basically your flag your
your app is asking for flag evaluations
with some context data passing that
through the open feature SDK and then
the open feature SDK is interacting with
a provider say dev cycle at this point
um and that and then the dev cycle
provider is what's actually making the
decisions on what values that that flag
should have and sort of routing that
back through um the open feature SDK
through the provider interface um so
simply uh the multi-provider as it's
it's actually a pretty well-n named um
uh thing we get very very rarely we
actually name things well but I think
multi provider is pretty good um it
allows you to combine multiple uh
providers together in a single interface
to the open feature SDK so um you have
your flags arrest provider um and now
you have you also have your flags not us
um service that can combine together um
to provide values to the open feature
SDK and to your application and so these
uh these different providers are
connected through what we call
strategies so there's a couple
strategies I'll go through here today um
that actually determine sort of which
value to be used from the different
providers um there's a first match
strategy there's a first successful
strategy a comparison strategy and you
can write your own custom logic um this
is currently supported in the Node.js
and web SDKs um and if you'd like us to
support it in other places um come chat
with me after uh the setup for the
multi-rovider is fairly straightforward
um you grab the multi-provider class
from the multi-provider package and then
you provide multiple providers to it
fairly straightforward so we have the
flags are us and the flags not us
providers here and then you pass in the
the multi-provider to open open features
set provider method i'm using the set
provider and weight method here um and
then you access um your feature flags
through the open feature client um as
you normally would for for any other um
setup and and
provider um so I go through the
strategies pretty quickly here the
default strategy is um the first match
strategy so this actually will will
evaluate these different providers in
order so um based on the order of the
array of the providers that you you
define um it'll it'll evaluate them in
order pretty simply um importantly it's
based on the provider responding with a
flag not found um error um uh when it
doesn't actually have a value for that
flag this is important because not every
provider implements this correctly um we
were one of those providers for a while
that didn't do it correctly so um yeah
it's important metadata that the the
provider sort of tells open feature that
um it's not that this uh the value for
this flag is erroring out it's just that
we don't have um this flag in our in our
system and we don't have a value for it
um and that basically tells the
multi-provider that okay it's not it's
not that it's erroring out it's just
that we don't have a value for it so
we're going to move on to the next
provider and try to evaluate it there um
this uh strategy will throw errors from
the provider so if there is an
underlying error that's thrown from one
of these providers it'll be thrown um uh
and the use case the the main use case
for the first match strategy is really
migrating between providers so this this
is might this might be an a case where
um you want to sort of migrate to a new
vendor or a new open source project and
you're going to say hey I'm going to
keep all my existing flags on my old
system and I'm going to sort of keep all
the new flags and make sure everyone in
my company creates all the new flags in
the new system right and so you might
you might put the the new flagging
system first and the old flagging system
second um and this pretty simply will
will work pretty well for that use case
where you can be like um I want to
migrate providers but I don't actually
want to go through all the effort of
like copying flags between the different
providers um yeah the second strategy um
is the first successful strategy so
pretty similar to the first match
strategy um except errors do not halt
execution um basically the first
successful execution from a provider is
returned um an errors thrown if there's
no successful execution um basically
this is more of like a you want to have
a fallback so say you want to have like
a low if you're having issues with a
vendor or or a product that maybe is is
having is throwing some errors in
certain situations um and you want to
have like a local fall fall back to like
a flags from a config file or
environment variables or something like
that um that that's uh this strategy
would be helpful for that
um probably one of the most interesting
ones and this actually came from a a use
case from from one of our customers or a
couple of our customers now is a
comparison strategy so this strategy you
can see that the setup is um a bit more
complex there but um all providers must
agree on um a value so it basically is
comparing the values returned um by both
providers and ensuring that basically
they the values agree um and if it they
don't agree you can see there there's
kind of like a resolutions call back um
where you can actually get the the
resolution values for the comparison
between the twoI two providers and in
this case um there's actually a special
run mode of of the the strategy where
all providers will be evaluated in
parallel so you could actually extend
this if you want to actually compare the
performance of different providers as
well and their execution performance of
of um your feature flags um and yeah the
main use case for this is obviously sort
of you're trying to do a full migration
from one vendor or one one open source
project to another where you actually
want all the values to be copied from
from sort of one source to the other and
ensure that they're actually um running
correctly and yeah and this I've seen
this multiple times um with with with
folks who are running migrations with us
where they want to actually test in
production that um they have all their
flags set up the same way in DevCycle
than they have them in flagd D or some
other source um and and they want to
ensure that the the values in production
actually match um and are getting
returned correctly so this is a very
powerful strategy for for those trying
to do full sort of migrations from um
from one vendor to the next um and then
yeah pretty simply if you want to set up
your own strategy uh you want to extend
one of these other strategies or or set
up your own um it's pretty easy to do
there's only a couple things you need to
set up so um there's a run mode that
just that that's what sort of um uh
that's what determines whether it's
going to run in parallel or sequentially
um the first method you need to
implement is called should evaluate this
provider so this is actually called
before a provider is evaluated um and
and you can put some logic in there to
determine whether the multi-provider
should should um actually evaluate that
provider um then we we obviously do
should evaluate next provider so after
evaluating the first provider um it
determines whether you should proceed or
not to evaluate the next one and then
finally uh determine final results so
this is kind of once you've evaluated
all the providers based off uh the the
first two methods um it's what will sort
of collect the values and return the the
value to the open feature SDK to return
it to your application um so yeah if you
have a theory of like I have this crazy
idea that I want to combine multiple
providers I want to combine like an
in-memory provider with a vendor with um
some old API i have um you can probably
write a custom provider that does that
um pretty pretty easily with this
interface
um but yeah that's it that's my
lightning talk so yeah if you have any
other use cases for multi-provider um
please come chat with me um yeah I'd be
be interested to hear sort of what other
thoughts um people have of like weird
use cases that you maybe haven't been
able to accomplish with open feature in
the past um and yeah if you're
interested in bringing the
multi-provider to more languages uh
please reach out uh to us in the open
feature CNCF Slack and yeah happy to
answer any questions if you might have
them
any questions yeah go ahead
uh thanks that was really interesting i
was wondering so the use case I think of
migration seems like a a pretty obvious
one for this um does it mean though that
then both of the providers need to be
open feature compatible or is there any
kind of workaround there yeah so you
would need to have an open feature
provider for for the two services um one
thing else I've been working on is a
what's called a codegen which is
basically a fancy script that can help
modify your code to actually convert a
codebase from say um using dev cycle or
launch darkly to using open feature as
the base SDK layer across your code and
then you can layer in the multi-provider
into that codegen to then be like okay
um we're gonna convert your codebase
from like dev cycle to open feature then
we're going to add in a a multi-provider
to like run one of these strategies to
to do a comparison between multiple
vendors um and so that's this is sort of
was the first step to to enable this
behavior and I think layering on things
like codegen and other things will help
um really try to get people onboarded to
like adopting open feature and get over
the hurdles of like the lock in that
that comes from uh from using thousands
of feature flies across your codebase
